channel.title: Fishing as an Npc rather than Object
channel.description: Does anyone happen to know (or care to guess) why Fishing Spots are Npcs rather than Objects?

item.title: Fishing as an Npc rather than Object
item.dc:creator: @silabsoft RuneAgent
item.description:
@silabsoft wrote:

[quote=“sinisoul, post:41, topic:549864”][quote author=Rodgerwilco link=topic=668747.msg4472636#msg4472636 date=1423977914]

Anyways, you guys are overlooking this waaayyy to much. The reason they are npcs and cows objects is due to pro antibotting technology.

[/quote][/quote]

that would only apply for dairy cows directly that was something added during the antibotting phase of rs2 originally you could use a bucket on any cow even during early rs2. Fishing spots have always been npcs

Read full topic
item.source: Fishing as an Npc rather than Object

item.title: Fishing as an Npc rather than Object
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

By definition, all NPCs “have” health, so that doesn’t really mean anything. We just know that their health isnt tied to when they move

Read full topic
item.source: Fishing as an Npc rather than Object

item.title: Fishing as an Npc rather than Object
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:37, topic:549864”][quote author=arham 4 link=topic=668747.msg4472613#msg4472613 date=1423961022]

[quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=668747.msg4472308#msg4472308 date=1423807674]
They do move though. Which is why you can have a fishing spot right clicked before it moves, hover over the fishing option, and then once it moves you click and you will move to the new location. Go ahead and try it right now, I can guarantee it will work. In some locations they move instantly (giving the false assumption they just disappear/reappear), and in others they actually have a generated path they follow to move (I think Karamja is an example of this, when they move from the pier to the beach)
[/quote]Er, if they moved, wouldn’t the players follow it and keep fishing while it moves?
[/quote]No? Why would that happen? Walk-to and follow actions are completely different

[quote author=arham 4 link=topic=668747.msg4472613#msg4472613 date=1423961022]
The same exact thing would happen if the NPC was just moved to a different coordinate and not “walking”.
[/quote]Correct, that’s what I said. I said teleported (aka “moved”) OR walking.[quote author=sk8rdude461 link=topic=668747.msg4472621#msg4472621 date=1423967454]

Has anyone considered the this:

Each npc has "health"
As you catch a fish from each npc, you take it’s “health” away.
At 0 “health” it “dies”.
And then it respawns to a new location.

nah fishing spots change regardless of use.

Shh. Shh. Let me be right.
[/quote]She is right, if you just stand in one spot next to a bunch of fishing spots with none of them being used you will still see them move[/quote]
That doesn’t mean my theory is wrong…
Just because they move on their own doesn’t mean they don’t have health…

Read full topic
item.source: Fishing as an Npc rather than Object

item.title: Fishing as an Npc rather than Object
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“arham 4, post:33, topic:549864”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=668747.msg4472308#msg4472308 date=1423807674]
They do move though. Which is why you can have a fishing spot right clicked before it moves, hover over the fishing option, and then once it moves you click and you will move to the new location. Go ahead and try it right now, I can guarantee it will work. In some locations they move instantly (giving the false assumption they just disappear/reappear), and in others they actually have a generated path they follow to move (I think Karamja is an example of this, when they move from the pier to the beach)
[/quote]Er, if they moved, wouldn’t the players follow it and keep fishing while it moves?[/quote]No? Why would that happen? Walk-to and follow actions are completely different

arham 4:

The same exact thing would happen if the NPC was just moved to a different coordinate and not “walking”.

Has anyone considered the this:

Each npc has "health"
As you catch a fish from each npc, you take it’s “health” away.
At 0 “health” it “dies”.
And then it respawns to a new location.

nah fishing spots change regardless of use.
[/quote]

Shh. Shh. Let me be right.[/quote]She is right, if you just stand in one spot next to a bunch of fishing spots with none of them being used you will still see them move

Read full topic

item.title: Fishing as an Npc rather than Object
item.dc:creator: @arham_4 arham 4
item.description:
@arham_4 wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:16, topic:549864”][quote author=Miss Silabsoft link=topic=668747.msg4472307#msg4472307 date=1423807103]

This is a very good question actually, I’ve always thought it had something to do with the fact that the fishing spots “move”.
[/quote]This is exactly the reason, as I said. The claims made that they don’t “walk”, and only disappear/reappear are false (while that may happen for some or even most of the spots, I can distinctly remember seeing some of them move like an NPC in a walking path)

they don’t move though, one fishing spot gets flagged invisible the other gets flagged visible this can be verified if you ever botted rs you would know the same fishing npcs have different array indexes
[/quote]They do move though. Which is why you can have a fishing spot right clicked before it moves, hover over the fishing option, and then once it moves you click and you will move to the new location. Go ahead and try it right now, I can guarantee it will work. In some locations they move instantly (giving the false assumption they just disappear/reappear), and in others they actually have a generated path they follow to move (I think Karamja is an example of this, when they move from the pier to the beach)[/quote]Er, if they moved, wouldn’t the players follow it and keep fishing while it moves?

[quote=“Davidi2, post:18, topic:549864”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=668747.msg4472308#msg4472308 date=1423807674]
They do move though. Which is why you can have a fishing spot right clicked before it moves, hover over the fishing option, and then once it moves you click and you will move to the new location. Go ahead and try it right now, I can guarantee it will work.

http://forums.zybez.net/topic/1345543-moving-fishing-spots/

etc etc.

That effect wouldn’t occur unless it was the same NPC index moving to the new location.[/quote]The same exact thing would happen if the NPC was just moved to a different coordinate and not “walking”.

Read full topic

item.title: Fishing as an Npc rather than Object
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“Miss Silabsoft, post:30, topic:549864”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=668747.msg4472423#msg4472423 date=1423869409]

im not quite sure if theres any instances of an item being used on an noc other than after the summoning/pets release. and it seems rather dumb to make a packet for one cow.
[/quote]Well, considering cat pets were added VERY early into RS (before summoning, even in OSRS I believe) that would be one example of item on npc. And I’m pretty sure some combat monsters for quests have you using an item on them to weaken them or something.

you had the cat they were not a pet until rs2. they would just take up space in the inventory.[/quote]Well yeah, rs2. Nobody here is talking about classic. that would be completely different

Read full topic

item.title: Fishing as an Npc rather than Object
item.dc:creator: @Vain1 Vain_
item.description:
@Vain1 wrote:

yeah. 8689 is the dairy cow object.

so it probably is only due the way the engine handled packets back in the day.

as in objects not supporting animations for the fish to be an npc
and perhaps a default “item on npc” packet never being handled?

im not quite sure if theres any instances of an item being used on an noc other than after the summoning/pets release. and it seems rather dumb to make a packet for one cow.

Read full topic

item.description:
@runescape_sucks wrote:

siege engine:

I guess because a fishing spot is a group of fish (i.e a group of npc’s, like a swarm)

This shouldn’t be a real reason. The cows that you milk are objects afaik.

Read full topic

item.title: Fishing as an Npc rather than Object
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

Not exactly. Theres a flag in the client to make you face the appropriate side but for some objects theres a specific location you need to be at before an action starts.

Read full topic
item.source: Fishing as an Npc rather than Object

item.title: Fishing as an Npc rather than Object
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“sinisoul, post:24, topic:549864”]Not exactly. There’s actually a lot of times where the path sent from the client is ignored and the server fabricates a path. ex: Proper alignment in furnaces. If that was the case, and I think the case where you would expect this to be true where you click and you move to the next spot would be a case of the NPC teleporting which by all means is very plausible. The NPC Walking there however? No.[/quote]The client actually calculates proper alignment for furnaces, and other interactable objects. I’m not sure how exactly (I would guess the interact location is somewhere in the object def?), but I actually realized that a while back when working on the official server. If you are right next to an object, but on the wrong side of it (for example ground levers, the winch for the flag on lumby castles, etc) it will still have you walk to the correct location. As for whether or not the fishing spot actually ‘walks’ to the new location, I’m not sure. I thought I remembered it doing that, but I’m not sure when exactly I remember it from (IE - if I could find it on OSRS) so I can’t double check. But either way, the NPC teleporting is still moving, keeping the same ID, which is why it would be a NPC and not an object (which is what the topic is about, :P). I cant find a bot that gives you entity indexes unfortunately to test, and I’m too lazy to write a script for one to do it myself.

If it does turn out to not need to ‘move’, then I guess the answer to OP would be as simple as [quote=“Tatemo, post:22, topic:549864”]Fish are living beings They are NPCs not objects.[/quote]

Read full topic
item.source: Fishing as an Npc rather than Object

item.title: Fishing as an Npc rather than Object
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

Not exactly. There’s actually a lot of times where the path sent from the client is ignored and the server fabricates a path. ex: Proper alignment in furnaces. If that was the case, and I think the case where you would expect this to be true where you click and you move to the next spot would be a case of the NPC teleporting which by all means is very plausible. The NPC Walking there however? No.

I’m willing to bet that there is an AI behavior for fishing spots that selects a random spot and teleports the spot there. Which would look something like:

onAiBehavior(fishing_move_spot, local function move_spot()
  delay(time)
  tele(some_random_spot)
  fork(move_spot)
end)

Read full topic
item.source: Fishing as an Npc rather than Object

item.title: Fishing as an Npc rather than Object
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“sinisoul, post:19, topic:549864”]No. That’s not definite proof. That’s server sided, you can easily force people to walk to the other active spot.[/quote]It’s an interact message, meaning the client calculates a path based on the given Entity and sends a walking queue message, and then an NPC interact message. You’re saying the server then ignores that walking queue message, finds the different NPC, and then recalculates the walking queue for it? I guess it wouldn’t be that hard, but it seems rather counter intuitive. What would the reason be behind that, when simply moving the NPC would produce the exact same result with less calculating required? And again, I still distinctly remember seeing fish move around like any other NPC.

I am going to find a working bot that has debug information to see if I can see NPC indexes, because it is possible that I’m remembering them moving incorrectly, but I am like 85% sure.

Read full topic
item.source: Fishing as an Npc rather than Object

@zuppers wrote:

I always assumed it’s the same npc just teleporting to new positions. As what david said we at least know it’s the same npc index id because if you right click a fishing spot then wait for it to move before you hit fish. You will just walk to the new position and start fishing.
